ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Understanding the role of sports in American society overtime.
This course helped me maintain and develop my writing skills, as well as gave me much better foundational knowledge of this history of sports and how it relates to the history of society overall
learned a lot about the origin of sport in the US
Better critical reading habits, how to form arguments, and how to decipher primary sources.

I developed my comprehension skills through intensive historical reading. The main thing I learned is that sports are about more than just achieving the best result. Politics take a significant part in sports too, making them an important part of many historical events.

This course was very good at developing historical thinking skills (this didn't have to happen this way, why did it happen this way, at this time, etc?). Of course, I learned a lot about the history of sports in America and how sports have developed from their (very different looking) roots to today, but I think that historical thinking mindset was an important part of the course as well.
learned a vast history of sports within the U.S.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is interesting and the content is fascinating. The structure of the course was not ideal, with close to half the class time spent on quizzes and discussions about deadlines and the value of history. It is a great class, it just gets irritating when the time we have isn't spent on content.
The chronological order was easy to track and follow. Wish we could have gotten a little into more modern times + fully covered the mid 20th century.
super interesting topic l, no weaknesses

The course was very well organized. It was clear what are we supposed to do throughout the semester. However, I would prefer to have a reading plan for the whole semester before the start of classes to prepare for it better. With my athletic responsibilities, I felt like I don't have enough time to prepare.

The course was a discussion seminar-style which allowed students to voice their thoughts and engage with the history. I thought the polls at the beginning of every class were very cool and fun ways to get the class involved and talking about modern sports issues, issues that are highly related to developments that occurred in sports history.

strengths: 
- very in depth knowledge
- enjoyed thorough conversations/debates on subjects

weaknesses:
- excessive amounts of assigned readings made it hard to retain all the information

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The learning itself was not at all negatively impacted so far as I could tell by the pandemic, as the transition to virtual learning seemed like it did not limit what I was able to learn. The only thing I feel I truly missed out on was a trip to the Stacks and library archives to look at/read/utilize the materials there for my benefit.
none could have been improved
The Zoom environment was used effectively, the discussion format worked really well. Everybody had the opportunity to express themselves.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Take this class. You will get to talk about sports and their origins, it covers a writing credit, and the readings are interesting on the whole. It skews toward white athletes, so take that as a pro or con. Sometimes the lack of diversity of background limits the kinds of discussions that are had, but that can also keep everyone on the same page.
The course has interesting readings and engaging discussion. The amount of reading varies week to week.
Yes absolutely: very interesting course, wonderful instructor, one of my favorite courses so far at Yale
this was one of the best courses i have taken

I would recommend this course to every first-year student. Not only the course is very enjoyable and interesting, but it helps the student to adjust to the heavy reading load and helps the student to improve speaking skills.
I would definitely recommend this course to anybody who enjoys sports and wants to learn more about how sports developed in America, as many things will surprise even the most devoted fans of sports.

comments: n/a
